ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Drinking alcohol when you are HIV positive is shameful.
Notes: 1= Strong Disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neutral; 4= Agree; 5 Strongly Agree

ElementDescription: People who are HIV positive and stop drinking alcohol are more responsible.
Notes: 1= Strong Disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neutral; 4= Agree; 5 Strongly Agree

ElementDescription: People who are HIV positive should not be allowed to drink alcohol.
Notes: 1= Strong Disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neutral; 4= Agree; 5 Strongly Agree

ElementDescription: Healthcare providers should scold HIV positive people who drink alcohol.
Notes: 1= Strong Disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neutral; 4= Agree; 5 Strongly Agree

ElementDescription: People who drink alcohol should not be allowed to take antiretroviral (ARVs) treatment .
Notes: 1= Strong Disagree; 2= Disagree; 3= Neutral; 4= Agree; 5 Strongly Agree

ElementDescription: How many times do you take your ARVs in a 24-hour period?
Notes: 1= Once a day regimen; 2= Twice a day regimen; 3= More than twice a day

ElementDescription: Have you ever had a viral load test performed? A viral load test is a blood test that measures the amount of HIV virus in your body.
Was your last viral load test result detectable or undetectable?
Everyone misses their pills sometimes. In the past 30 days, how many doses (pills) did you not take?
Notes: Number of Doses; 9999= Do Not Know

ElementDescription: In the past 30 days, on how many days did you miss at least one dose of your HIV medications?
Notes: Number of Days; 9999= Do Not Know

ElementDescription: In the past 30 days, how often did you take your ARVs in the way you were supposed to?
The last time you missed a pill, what was the main reason?
Notes: 1= Forgetting; 2= Too tired; 3= Drinking alcohol ; 4= Work obligations; 5= Did not have enough food; 6= Travelling away from home;7= Drug side effects; 8= Sick; 9= Had to care for relatives; 10= Transport costs;  11= Ran out of pills; 12= Quarrelling with partner; 13= Never missed a pill; 14= Funeral; 15= Other reasons

ElementDescription: If other, for why you missed a pill, please specify:
In the past 3 months, have you ever missed a pill (ARV) because of drinking alcohol?
In the past 3 months, how many times have you gone four or more days in a row without taking any of your ARVs?
Notes: Number of Times; 9999= Do Not Know

ElementDescription: In the past 6 months, have you ever missed an appointment with your HIV healthcare provider?
Have you ever stopped ARVs for 2 months or more?

Now I am going to give you a bowl of beans. Pretend that these are the ARVs you take each month. So if you take ARVs once per day, there are 30 beans for the month. If you take ARVs twice per day, there are 60 beans. Please select the number of beans corresponding to the ARVs you did not take in the last month and put them in the second bowl.
In the past 3 months, have you ever missed an appointment with your HIV healthcare provider?

Now I want you to show me how much of your antiretroviral (ARVs) you have taken over the past 30 days. Thinking back over the past 30 days, how much of your ARVs did you actually take? Show on the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) line below how much of your ARVs you took.
Is your partner currently taking antiretroviral (ARVs)?
How many times does your partner take their antiretroviral (ARVs) in a 24-hour period?
Notes: 1= Once a day regimen; 2= Twice a day regimen; 3= More than twice a day

ElementDescription: In the past 30 days, how many doses of antiretroviral (ARV pills) did your partner not take?
In the past 30 days, how often did your partner take their antiretroviral (ARVs) in the way they were supposed to?
Notes: 0= Never; 1= Rarely; 2= Sometimes; 3= Usually; 4= Almost always; 5= Always

ElementDescription: Thinking back over the past 30 days, how much of their antiretroviral (ARVs) do you believe they actually took in the past 30 days? Show on the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) line below the amount of their ARVs you think your partner has taken in the past 30 days.
In the past three months when you went to collect your antiretroviral (ARVs), did anyone at the clinic ask you if you take alcohol?
In the last 3 months, did anyone working at the clinic discuss with you about alcohol and antiretroviral (ARVs)?
When you started antiretroviral (ARVs), you were invited to attend treatment counseling. Who attended antiretroviral therapy (ART) counseling with you?
Notes: 0= Never attended counseling; 1= No one (attended alone); 2= Primary partner/spouse; 3= Sibling; 4= Parent; 5= Child; 6= Other relative; 7= Friend/neighbor; 8= Other sexual partner; 9= Other; 10= Previous spouse/primary partner

ElementDescription: When you started antiretroviral (ARVs), you were invited to attend treatment counseling. Who attended antiretroviral therapy (ART) counseling with you? Other, specify
Who is currently your designated treatment guardian?
Notes: 0= No one; 1= Primary partner/spouse; 2= Sibling; 3= Parent; 4= Child; 5= Other relative; 6= Friend/neighbor; 7= Other sexual partner; 8= Other

ElementDescription: Who is currently your designated treatment guardian? Other, specify
In the past 3 months, has your partner ever picked up your antiretroviral (ARVs) for you?
